faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Answers built from real AI-first projects — for teams turning software intelligence into hardware execution.

talent.title: Talent Execution
talent.q1: How quickly can you deliver qualified candidates for AI hardware roles?
talent.a1: We deliver the first candidate batch within 48 hours for most AI hardware roles. Our AI-driven search process and China+ network let us match engineers, supply-chain specialists, and production experts fast — so AI-first teams can start building hardware execution capability immediately.
talent.q2: What types of roles do you typically fill for AI hardware companies?
talent.a2: We focus on key execution roles across manufacturing, supply-chain, and quality — including Hardware Engineers, Manufacturing Engineers, Supply Chain Managers, Quality Engineers, Production Managers, and TPMs experienced in AI hardware ramp-up.
talent.q3: Do you provide support after placement?
talent.a3: Yes — we stay engaged. RobotLinked offers 3-month post-placement support for onboarding, cultural integration, and performance feedback.
talent.q4: How do you ensure candidates understand both AI and manufacturing?
talent.a4: Every candidate is pre-screened for AI / robotics knowledge and hands-on manufacturing experience. We use a competency framework built for AI-hardware execution.

solutions.title: Supply Chain Acceleration
solutions.q1: What's included in your production feasibility assessment?
solutions.a1: Our 10-day assessment covers component sourcing analysis, supplier evaluation, cost modeling, timeline priorities, and risk recommendations for pilot-to-mass transition.
solutions.q2: How do you help with component sourcing for AI hardware?
solutions.a2: We use our China+ supplier network to source critical components (sensors, motors, optics, PCBs etc.), managing validation, cost negotiation, and quality assurance throughout the process.
solutions.q3: What support do you provide during production ramp-up?
solutions.a3: Our on-site engineering team handles yield optimization, quality control, and supplier coordination during the critical ramp-up phase to ensure on-time delivery.

general.title: Strategy & Operations
general.q1: What's your recommended approach for AI hardware manufacturing strategy?
general.a1: We suggest a China+ multi-region approach — prototype in China for speed and ecosystem access, then scale to other regions based on cost and market needs. This balances speed and supply-chain resilience.
general.q2: How do you handle cross-cultural and language barriers?
general.a2: Our bilingual execution team bridges engineering intent and factory execution through standardized processes and clear documentation.
general.q3: What makes RobotLinked different from traditional consulting firms?
general.a3: RobotLinked is not a consulting firm — we're an embedded execution partner for AI-first teams. We combine lightweight structure, AI-native workflow, and China+ supply chain expertise to turn design into reality.
general.q4: Do you support manufacturing outside of China due to tariff concerns?
general.a4: Yes, we can help navigate alternative manufacturing locations when tariffs or geopolitical factors are a concern. We identify suppliers with relevant capabilities in regions like Southeast Asia, India, or Mexico, and provide on-site resources to ensure quality and coordination. Our global network allows us to maintain the same level of manufacturing excellence regardless of location.

contact.title: Still have questions?

clients.title: Six Core Challenges We Solve for AI-First Teams
clients.subtitle: Software-led companies entering hardware face unique challenges. We provide embedded execution support — from building hardware capabilities to scaling manufacturing in China+.

challenge1.title: From Model to Machine
challenge1.trigger: AI models need real-world carriers — but productizing hardware requires a different skill set.
challenge1.problem: AI-first teams excel at software but lack hardware execution and supply chain expertise.
challenge1.solution: Deploy experienced engineers to accelerate hardware development; Establish frameworks ensuring smooth design-to-production handoff.

challenge2.title: Building Hardware Capabilities Fast
challenge2.trigger: Software teams know how to hire engineers — but hardware roles require different competencies.
challenge2.problem: Unclear role definitions and missing frameworks slow down critical hardware team building.
challenge2.solution: Define clear roles and deliver pre-screened shortlists; Provide frameworks and competency models for AI hardware teams.

challenge3.title: Supplier Readiness & Risk Control
challenge3.trigger: Even the best design requires suppliers who can deliver consistent quality at scale.
challenge3.problem: Critical components often lack proper validation, causing spec gaps and yield instability.
challenge3.solution: Deploy SQE and sourcing experts to validate suppliers; Establish specification standards with structured validation protocols.

challenge4.title: Engineering-to-Manufacturing Sync
challenge4.trigger: AI teams iterate fast, but hardware validation can't keep up without on-site support.
challenge4.problem: Engineering changes and production issues face slow resolution due to time zones and communication gaps.
challenge4.solution: Station on-site PMs and engineers for real-time issue resolution; Implement tight tracking loops with clear ownership.

challenge5.title: Scale Smartly, Not Blindly
challenge5.trigger: AI companies often scale prematurely before the design-manufacturing loop stabilizes.
challenge5.problem: Aggressive timelines and cost targets create strain without proper planning and visibility.
challenge5.solution: Assign cost engineers and SCM managers to optimize planning; Provide real-time dashboards for cost and delivery transparency.

challenge6.title: Design to Mass Production
challenge6.trigger: Getting from CAD to production-ready requires bridging design intent with manufacturing reality.
challenge6.problem: Cross-border teams struggle with communication gaps, cultural differences, and compliance requirements.
challenge6.solution: Deploy bilingual PMs to bridge global and local teams; Provide compliance checklists and bilingual documentation.

why_choose.title: Why AI-First Teams Choose RobotLinked to Build Hardware Capabilities
why_choose.subtitle: We understand the unique challenges AI-first teams face when entering hardware — and provide embedded execution support, not just consulting.

challenge1.label: Hardware-Specific Expertise
challenge1.problem: AI-first teams need people who understand both software iteration culture and hardware validation constraints.
challenge1.solution: We match candidates with dual fluency: experienced in China manufacturing and familiar with AI-first workflows.

challenge2.label: Rapid Team Formation
challenge2.problem: You don't have months to wait for a traditional search firm to deliver shortlists — you need talent now.
challenge2.solution: Our AI-native workflow and deep China network deliver first candidate batch in 48 hours for most roles.

challenge3.label: China+ Embedded Teams
challenge3.problem: Hiring remotely in China without local guidance leads to cultural mismatches and high attrition.
challenge3.solution: We provide pre-vetted, locally embedded candidates who bridge global HQ and China manufacturing.

challenge4.label: Retention & Delivery Reliability
challenge4.problem: High turnover in the first 90 days derails hardware timelines and burns runway.
challenge4.solution: Our candidates come with structured 30/60/90-day onboarding plans and cultural fit assessments.

process_new.title: AI-Native Recruitment Workflow
process_new.subtitle: Built for speed, transparency, and precision — designed for hardware teams that can't wait.

step1.title: Role Scoping & Competency Mapping
step1.desc: We clarify role definitions, map competencies to your product stage (Pilot / EVT / DVT / MP), and define success criteria.

step2.title: AI-Powered Candidate Matching
step2.desc: Our AI workflow matches your JD against our vetted talent pool, prioritizing candidates with China manufacturing + AI-first experience.

step3.title: 48-Hour Shortlist Delivery
step3.desc: Receive candidate profiles with: technical background, project highlights, cultural fit notes, and reference validation.

step4.title: Interview Coordination & Offer Support
step4.desc: We coordinate interviews, provide compensation benchmarks, and support offer negotiation.

step5.title: 30/60/90-Day Onboarding
step5.desc: Structured onboarding plans with performance milestones, cultural integration support, and immediate replacement guarantee.

core_roles.title: Key Roles We Build for Hardware Execution
core_roles.subtitle: From NPI to mass production — we recruit the roles that move hardware forward.

manufacturing.title: Manufacturing & NPI Engineering
manufacturing.desc: Build teams who translate design into manufacturable products.
roles: NPI Program Manager — owns pilot-to-MP transition
Structural Engineer — ensures DFM and part validation
Test Engineer (TE) — builds EOL test systems

supply_chain.title: Supply Chain & Procurement
supply_chain.desc: Secure reliable suppliers and control costs at scale.
roles: Supply Chain Manager — end-to-end supplier & logistics coordination
Strategic Buyer — negotiate and qualify key component suppliers
Cost Engineer — cost modeling, should-cost analysis, BOM optimization
Logistics Coordinator — manage inbound/outbound, inventory, and customs

quality.title: Quality & Supplier Quality
quality.desc: Ensure yield stability and compliance from day one.
roles: SQE (Supplier Quality Engineer) — validate suppliers, manage NCRs
Quality Manager — build quality systems (ISO/IATF/IPC standards)
Failure Analysis Engineer — root cause analysis for yield improvement

leadership.title: Leadership & Program Management
leadership.desc: Bridge global HQ strategy with China execution.
roles: China General Manager — full P&L and operational ownership
Hardware Program Director — cross-functional execution leadership
Operations Director — manage factory relationships and capacity planning
Technical Program Manager (TPM) — coordinate eng, supply chain, and production

model1.title: On-Demand Placement

model2.best_for: Best for: Ongoing hiring needs (3+ roles over 6 months).

model3.title: Team-as-a-Service (Project-Based)

challenges.title: Hardware Manufacturing Challenges for AI-First Teams

challenge1.title: Hard to Find Reliable Suppliers
challenge1.desc: Fragmented ecosystems and trust gaps make it difficult to identify qualified partners.

challenge2.title: Lack of Hardware Execution Experience
challenge2.desc: Software-first teams unfamiliar with DFM, tooling, and vendor coordination processes.

challenge3.title: Prototype-to-Production Gaps
challenge3.desc: Fast design iterations outpace factory readiness, causing delays.

challenge4.title: Cross-Culture Communication Gaps
challenge4.desc: Misaligned expectations between global HQ and local suppliers create execution risks.

challenge5.title: Vendor Commitment Challenges
challenge5.desc: Early-stage startups are often deprioritized by large factories.

challenge6.title: Unoptimized Scaling Cost
challenge6.desc: Inefficient supplier mix and weak negotiation leverage drive up overhead.

privacy.title: Privacy Policy
privacy.subtitle: We value and protect your personal privacy

collection.title: Information Collection
collection.content: We only collect information necessary to provide our services, including company information, contact details, and business requirements you provide in contact forms. We do not collect your sensitive personal information unless you voluntarily provide it and our services require it.

usage.title: Information Usage
usage.content: We use the collected information to: (1) respond to your inquiries and provide professional services; (2) improve our service quality; (3) send relevant industry information and service updates (with your consent). We do not use your information for other commercial purposes.

protection.title: Information Protection
protection.content: We employ industry-standard security measures to protect your personal information, including encrypted transmission, access controls, and regular security reviews. We limit access to your personal information to employees who need to know.

sharing.title: Information Sharing
sharing.content: We do not sell, trade, or transfer your personal information to third parties. We may share necessary information with trusted service providers, but only as required to provide services, and they commit to protecting your information security.

cookies.title: Cookie Usage
cookies.content: Our website uses cookies to improve user experience, including remembering your language preferences and analyzing website usage. You can control cookie usage through your browser settings.

rights.title: Your Rights
rights.content: You have the right to request access, correction, or deletion of your personal information we hold. You may also request restrictions on or object to certain data processing activities. To exercise these rights, please contact us using the information below.

contact.title: Contact Us
contact.content: If you have any questions about this privacy policy or need assistance, please contact us:

terms.title: Terms of Service
terms.subtitle: Please read the following terms and conditions carefully

acceptance.title: Acceptance of Terms
acceptance.content: By accessing and using our website and services, you agree to comply with these terms of service. If you do not agree to these terms, please do not use our services. We reserve the right to modify these terms at any time.

services.title: Service Description
services.content: RobotLinked provides professional consulting services for AI hardware and robotics companies' manufacturing implementation, including talent services and solution services. Our service scope includes team building, supply chain management, manufacturing consulting, and other professional services.

obligations.title: User Obligations
obligations.content: You agree to: (1) provide truthful and accurate information; (2) not abuse our services; (3) comply with applicable laws and regulations; (4) respect our intellectual property; (5) not engage in any activities that may harm our services or reputation.

ip.title: Intellectual Property
ip.content: All content on our website, including text, images, logos, designs, etc., is protected by intellectual property laws. Without our explicit written permission, you may not copy, distribute, or otherwise use this content.

liability.title: Limitation of Liability
liability.content: To the maximum extent permitted by law, we are not liable for any direct, indirect, incidental, or consequential damages arising from the use of our services. Our total liability shall not exceed the fees you paid for the relevant services.

termination.title: Service Termination
termination.content: We reserve the right to suspend or terminate your use of our services at any time, especially if you violate these terms. After service termination, certain parts of the relevant terms will continue to be effective.

law.title: Governing Law
law.content: These terms are governed by the laws of the People's Republic of China. Any disputes arising from these terms should first be resolved through friendly consultation. If consultation fails, they shall be submitted to the competent people's court in Shenzhen.

changes.title: Terms Changes
changes.content: We may periodically update these terms of service. Significant changes will be notified through website announcements or other appropriate means. Continued use of our services indicates your acceptance of the revised terms.

contact.title: Contact Information
contact.content: If you have any questions about these terms of service, please contact us:
